messages.text: Is there a IDE for Julia that has code inspection features such as "show call hierarchy" (didn't seem to work for in vscode with Julia ext)?

text.text: Is there a IDE for Julia that has code inspection features such as "show call hierarchy" (didn't seem to work for in vscode with Julia ext)?

messages.text: Can you elaborate a bit on what you want in the 'show call heirarchy' feature? You want the set of methods that get called downstream by a given method?

text.text: Can you elaborate a bit on what you want in the 'show call heirarchy' feature? You want the set of methods that get called downstream by a given method?

messages.text: I think it's rather the other way round, the methods that call the method in question, recursively.

text.text: I think it's rather the other way round, the methods that call the method in question, recursively.

messages.text: This is generally a difficult thing to do in julia due to how generic code is. It can be done at least for code paths that have already run: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/finding-uses-of-a-method/32729/2>

attachments.title: Finding uses of a method?
attachments.text: You could potentially use Casette.jl to store the stacktrace every time a particular method is called. Apart from this, I do not think any such functionality exists.
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Finding uses of a method?

text.text: This is generally a difficult thing to do in julia due to how generic code is. It can be done at least for code paths that have already run: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/finding-uses-of-a-method/32729/2>

messages.text: is there a way to get something to iterate thorugh a string with broadcast(f, s) where s is a string

text.text: is there a way to get something to iterate thorugh a string with broadcast(f, s) where s is a string

messages.text: You could do  ``` julia> using OffsetArrays  julia> selectarray = OffsetVector([:a, :b, :c], -1:1) 3-element OffsetArray(::Vector{Symbol}, -1:1) with eltype Symbol with indices -1:1:  :a  :b  :c  julia> (⋚)(x, y) = x == y ? 0 : x < y ? -1 : 1 ⋚ (generic function with 1 method)  julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 2] :a  julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 1] :b  julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ -1] :c ``` where `⋚` is typed `\lesseqgtr` and then hit the tab key.

text.text:
You could do 
```
julia> using OffsetArrays

julia> selectarray = OffsetVector([:a, :b, :c], -1:1)
3-element OffsetArray(::Vector{Symbol}, -1:1) with eltype Symbol with indices -1:1:
 :a
 :b
 :c

julia> (⋚)(x, y) = x == y ? 0 : x < y ? -1 : 1
⋚ (generic function with 1 method)

julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 2]
:a

julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ 1]
:b

julia> selectarray[1 ⋚ -1]
:c
```
where `⋚` is typed `\lesseqgtr` and then hit the tab key.

messages.text: Julia has a lot of great Unicode support. If you’re writing user facing code, it’s good to support an interface that does not explicitly require using Unicode (so at least provide ASCII fallback) because there will always be someone with a backwards system that can’t render it right

text.text: Julia has a lot of great Unicode support. If you’re writing user facing code, it’s good to support an interface that does not explicitly require using Unicode (so at least provide ASCII fallback) because there will always be someone with a backwards system that can’t render it right

messages.text: But generally, if you find that using Unicode helps you write code you like, use it.

text.text: But generally, if you find that using Unicode helps you write code you like, use it.
